His Excellency Boris Yeltsin was welcomed by the Right Honourable Brian Mulroney, Prime Minister of Canada, and thanked by the Honourable Guy Charbonneau, Speaker of the Senate and the Honourable John A. Fraser, Speaker of the House of Commons.

speakeroldname: Hon. John A. Fraser (Speaker of the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: Order, please. The Right Honourable the Prime Minister.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, chers collegu.es, mesdames et messieurs. We are here today to celebrate the state visit to Canada by the President of the Russian Federation, His Excellency Boris Yeltsin. We are here, as well, to launch a new era of peace and partnership between peoples too long divided.
Fifty years ago this month, diplomatic relations were opened between Ottawa and Moscow. Diplomatic relations between us were bom, as it turns out, of absolute necessity during the darkest days of the Second World War. Europe then lay in subjugation and Russia lay under the darkest siege.
I have stood before the War Memorial in St. Petersburg in the brutal cold of winter and I have listened to the winds whisper silently of great tragedy and enormous human loss in Russia. I have visited cemeteries from Dieppe to Sai Wan Bay and I have heard courageous veterans mourn fallen comrades sacrificed in the defence of liberty and democracy against the very same enemy.

The establishment of diplomatic relations at that time was both an act of defiance toward those who wanted to destroy us and an act of hope for better days. We indeed finally defeated our common enemy, but our relations drifted into the great desolation of the cold war. We found ourselves facing each other in a new struggle, a war waged not on the plains of central Europe or in the jungles of Asia but in the hearts and minds of men and women throughout the world.
This war as well is now over; the victory was won not by one army over another but by fundamental values and powerful ideas to which all can adhere.

Obviously, Mr. Speaker and fellow Canadians, the largest measure of the credit for this unique opportunity that now opens down the vistas of years must be given to President Yeltsin.
Courage is an abstraction to those at a relatively safe distance. But as it turns out, President Yeltsin was given no such latitude.
In the crucial days of last August on the top of a tank, at immediate risk to his own life, he dispatched the tyranny that had held Russia in the grip of fear and arbitrary power for 70 years.
The image of Boris Yeltsin last summer and his defiant message to the enemies of democracy everywhere, particularly in his own country, will remain as an historic symbol of courage and purpose so long as men and women gather in free Parliaments to defend the cause of liberty. And I tell you, Mr. President, all Canadians salute you for the extraordinary courage that you have demonstrated.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: Hear, hear.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext:
President Yeltsin's success was the success fundamentally of the human spirit. His beneficiaries are us all.
Mr. President, you have offered us friendship and you have challenged us to join with you in bringing your country into the community of free nations. I know that I speak for every member of this House and that, sir, is a most rare occurrence.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: Hear, hear.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext:
As I told you, sir, on both sides of the House, all of them are active supporters of mine.
June 19, 1992

I speak for every member of this House irrespective of political party because every Canadian believes fundamentally in liberty and democracy. I speak for all Canadians, Canadians across this land, when I say that all Canadians reciprocate your friendship and today we accept your challenge.

The ancient Greeks taught us that democracy is government by the free. The people of Russia are not yet fully free of the dead hand of debilitating ideology and the victory of values is not yet complete.
Mr. President, we understand that the way ahead is fraught with serious difficulties, even perils, and that there will be setbacks and course corrections along the way. Here in this House of Canadian democracy, I give you the firm assurance of our understanding and support. So long as your compass is set for democracy, Canadians will be at your side, Canadians of all regions, of all political parties, of all parts of society.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: Hear, hear.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: Mr. President, on behalf of all members of Parliament and on behalf of all Canadians, it is with respect and admiration that I invite you today to address the Parliament and the people of Canada.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext:
Hear, hear.
[Editor's Note: Mr. Yeltsin spoke in Russian.] [Translation]
His Excellency Boris Yeltsin (President of the Russian Federation): Respected Speaker of the House of Commons, respected Speaker of the Senate, respected members of the House of Commons, respected senators, ladies and gentlemen, respected citizens of a free Canada.
First of all, Prime Minister Mulroney, I thank you for your kind words addressed to a free, democratic Russia and to its President.
Thank you for the warm reception. Like you, Mr. Mulroney, I do not always enjoy such a favourable reception in my own Parliament.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: Hear, hear.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext:
It is a great honour for me, the President of Russia, the first to be elected to the highest position of
a great state, to address you from the rostrum of the highest legislative body in Canada.
The moment has arrived when two peoples who have much in common can take a decisive step toward one another. Official relations between our countries, as you said, Mr. Prime Minister, were re-established 50 years ago. But today, unfortunately, one can see how little has been achieved, how many opportunities have been missed. Now we have a rare opportunity to make up for lost time.
When people speak about Russia and Canada, they generally comment on how similar our countries are. Canada is probably the only place where a Russian could forget that he is in a different country. The amazing similarity of the nature, climate and even the wide-open spaces of our countries has left an imprint on the character of Canadians and Russians.
I continually ask myself: given such similar circumstances, why have our countries developed so differently? Why do our peoples live so differently?
Canada is a recognized world leader in terms of quality of life. Life today in Russia is extremely disrupted, with conditions as tense as a taut string. It is easy to see the enormous, damage wreaked on Russia by the 70-year dominance of the Communist totalitarian system. Here in Canada there are no echoes of the arguments with which party ideologues formerly explained the terribly low quality of life which Russians experience. Neither its northern position, nor its harsh climate, nor the alleged nationalistic narrow-mindedness of the Russian people, nor malicious neighbours are to blame for Russia's failure to develop. The main cause lies in the anti-popular stance of the former regime, in the ideology that was forced on the country. For years, the foundations that support life were systematically destroyed. But the citizens of today's Russia do not simply mourn over lost opportunities. Your country is an especially visible and attractive example of the goals which we are now pursuing.
Last August, when we faced the coup-plotters, a very dark cloud loomed not only over Russia, but over the whole world. But the collapse of the totalitarian system was total. The collapse of communistic ideology was total. Once and forever.
As the first president in the thousand-year history of Russia to be elected by all the people, I triumphantly announce this to you. Once and forever.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext:
Hear, hear.

June 19, 1992

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext:
The first thing we want to do now is re-establish a normal country, with a normal economy and a normal life. Not a super life, but a normal human way of life. Our tragic past has convinced us that one of the highest treasures that any human community can have is a normal way of life.
Russia knows revolution only too well. That is why I say today on behalf of all Russians that Communist revolution is an evil. We have opted for normal evolution. Russia knows arbitrariness and lawlessness all too well. That is why we have chosen a state based on the rule of law. We are more familiar than other peoples with the nightmare of totalitarianism. That is why we have chosen democracy and why we defended it in those days of last August.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: Hear, hear.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: We know better than others what it is like to be everyone's enemy. That is why we have chosen openness and co-operation with the world community. Russia has opted for freedom, and no force can take it away from us.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: Hear, hear.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext:
"We don't need any more great upheavals. We need a great Russia." These words, spoken a century ago by Russian patriot and reformer Stolypin, have not lost their relevance. On the contrary, they are full of deep, immediate meaning for us. We want our people to raise children and work peacefully. We want them to be governed not by base social instincts or ideological delusions, but by just motives and thoughts. Today, we turn to your rich experience so that we can once and forever say no to all ideological delusions that demand human sacrifices and reject morality.
Borrowing the words of poetess Anna Akhmatova, I pledge to you as President that I will do everything to ensure that Russia never again lapses into the insanity of upheaval.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: Hear, hear.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext:
Broad new horizons have opened for Russian-Canadian co-operation. Half a century ago, our countries were allies in the anti-Hitler coalition. Today, when I visited the memorial to those who died in the First and Second World Wars and in other conflicts, I thought of the fact that Russia and Canada have never
fought against one another. This is a great achievement. There is a firm conviction today that we are closer to world peace than ever before. Today, when I passed the peace monument being built, it struck me that you have chosen the most appropriate moment possible to build it, when this confidence in peace is at its peak.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: Hear, hear.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext:
Half a century ago, our countries were allies in the anti-Hitler coalition. Today, we have every reason to speak of a new alliance between us. I am convinced that the need for this alliance has long been felt by those prepared to become direct participants in diverse Russian-Canadian contacts.
Both sides have no shortage of plans for co-operation. It is time we gave them the green light. From this point onward, there are no limits to co-operation between Russia and Canada in world affairs. We can pool our efforts in many different areas in order to strengthen international security, to withstand potential aggressors through collective action, to ensure that all the nations of the world observe the rules of civilized behaviour, including in their behaviour toward their own citizens and national minorities, and to solve global problems.
We applaud your policies of constructive internationalism. We ourselves have already begun to co-operate in working toward the goals identified by the international community. Your country's longstanding commitment to the United Nations organization and to institutions of multilateral diplomacy in general is well known. As is the role played by such outstanding Canadians as Mr. Pearson in working out ways to use the United Nations apparatus in peacekeeping.
This area of United Nations activity and preventive diplomacy aimed at averting conflict could become an ideal domain for applying our joint efforts. The importance of such international mechanisms is regrettably increasing, even in Europe. We have no intention of declaring Russia or any of the states that made up the former union off limits to necessary measures taken by the international community, whether through the United Nations organization or the CSCE. We want peace and calm in our house, in each family. We therefore have a stake in ensuring peace and calm outside it.
June 19, 1992

The opportunities for co-operation between Russia cine. Unpopular measures, including price increases, and Canada in world affairs are greater now than ever must be adopted in order to shift from a planned before. We must not let them slip by at this of all times, economy to a market economy. However difficult this
may be, we will not retreat.
Ladies and gentlemen, throughout history merchants have preceded diplomats. Such was the case in Russia before 1917. The first treaties were trade treaties. And economic co-operation occupies centre stage in Rus-sian-Canadian relations. Our people have goods to trade, and there are areas for co-operation. Russia is rich. All that is needed is an unbiased approach unhindered by preconceptions. Given such an approach, Rus-sian-Canadian co-operation offers substantial benefits to both parties.
For three hours yesterday and an hour today, Prime Minister Mulroney and I took part in discussions. The Government of Canada proposed a very interesting idea for developing our relations, an idea that could serve as an example for other countries as well. We particularly appreciate this, knowing that Canada too is experiencing difficulties at present. I feel that the high degree of mutual trust which characterizes our personal relations with the Prime Minister allows us to feel confident that this co-operation, these new ideas will be realized.
Russia has set a firm course toward economic reform. We realize that every last market mechanism was eradicated over a period of more than 70 years. After three generations, we have lost the historical instincts we once had for business and private ownership. No one remembers what they mean. We introduced private ownership only half a year ago, including private ownership of land and ownership by foreign private investors.
Practically no one is left who remembers life before the revolution. We realize that the economy is being overhauled during a serious economic crisis, and consequently at a time when the civil peace is highly vulnerable. But it cannot be denied that substantial progress has been achieved in half a year. There have been real changes both in the economy itself and, more important, in people's consciousness.
The people are gradually rediscovering the creativity that was crushed by Communist ideas and ideologies.
Of course, we are currently going through the most painful period, especially this year. This is bitter medi-
Russians are a patient, stubborn people. With gritted teeth, they will overcome these temporal difficulties. They trust their President. They trust their government. They trust their Parliament. And that is very important.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: Hear, hear.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: Every month, I find myself in various districts, regions and republics of Russia. There are 20 republics in Russia. And we have succeeded in signing a federative treaty. Blood is being spilled on Russia's doorstep, but inside Russia we have signed a treaty and preserved the civil peace without spilling a single drop of blood. Russia has remained united and indivisible throughout this period. That is very important to us.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: Hear, hear.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: Russia's young government of reformers the President of the Russian Federation will support to the end. And it is practically impossible now to force him into retirement. I will not resign until my term expires in 1996. You will never catch me sick. I am extremely healthy. I will therefore support this government of reformers to the end.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: Hear, hear.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: We took our first steps toward a market economy on January 1 of this year. The main one was the freeing of prices, and the government is prepared to take the reforms further. You know that before leaving on this official visit, I asked Parliament to confirm Mr. Gaidar, who is currently acting in my place, as Prime Minister of the Head of State of the Russian Federation. And he is only 36 years old. He is a bold, young reformer.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: Hear, hear.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: One of the main principles for choosing people to serve in the government, as ministers or vice-president, besides considering their professional or business skills, is to select democrats and ensure that none of them is older than the President.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: Hear, hear.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext:
We call for full co-operation with other countries. I am confident that a revival of the Russian economy will be beneficial not only to us, but to our partners as well. If you invite our specialists, talented young people, to come and study, after studying in Canada for a year, they will return to Russia to advocate Canadian experience, the Canadian market and the Canadian economy. And this co-operation will develop still further.
I believe that one of these people, who will number approximately 150 over five years, as the Prime Minister and I agreed today, may very well develop into a new and talented President of Russia to follow me.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: Hear, hear.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext:
Of course, I am sure that new president will be more talented and more intelligent. That is understandable. Such is history. Today, Russia attaches special importance to western investment and co-operation in the technical field. Today, we agreed on technical co-operation aimed at ensuring the safety of nuclear power plants. We have a program drawn up. The fact that it will be implemented through joint efforts is a complete guarantee that all nuclear power plants will be absolutely free of danger and under the control of the IAEA.
We are not asking for any special injections of money or materials. I want to be quite forthright about that. If Canada did find an opportunity of this kind then, of course, it would help us overcome our problems in this very painful period.
It is true that Russia does not yet offer all of the conditions necessary for accepting private capital from abroad. But before this visit, a series of laws were adopted and decrees promulgated that clear the way for private capital, mainly by making it possible to own property and land, thus facilitating the construction or privatization of factories, buildings, and so on. It is our firm intention to promote this process energetically and to complete it in the very near future.
To achieve this, there is no need to invent anything new. Our course, our norms and standards are those accepted throughout the world. I realize that many Canadian firms are not waiting for an ideal investment climate to develop in Russia. That is how one must act:
without being afraid of taking a risk. I do not doubt that this risk is worth taking. Any western investor who fails to enter this unique Russian market this year or next should keep in mind that 1994 will be too late: there will be no room left in the market.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: Hear, hear.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext:
There is no other way open to us, no alternative to normal economic development. When Russia is rich and flourishing, as I am certain that it will be, we will surely not forget those who were the first to take a risk, a warranted risk.
We have an area for bilateral co-operation that has always attracted much attention: the Arctic. We are much concerned about the situation in the far north of Russia and Canada. The spectrum of problems ranges from the status of aboriginal peoples to environment protection.
Of course, our problems differ in scale. The entire population of the Canadian Arctic is around 100,000. You have no major industrial centres above the Arctic Circle. But I think that I am not mistaken in saying that only together can we solve all of the problems involving the Arctic. Only by working together. Of this I am convinced.
The prosperity of the countries in this region, and above all of Canada and Russia, depend in large measure on conditions in the Arctic. Experience has shown that co-operation between us in this area cannot develop exclusively through dialogue between our capitals. We must therefore emphasize immediate links between the direct participants in co-operation, and above all between the people who actually live in these Arctic regions. They are more interested than anyone in seeing prosperity and the well-being that follows come to their extremely forbidding land.
There is another area of mutual interest in the Russian-Canadian dialogue that might be opened up for further avenues of bilateral co-operation. I wanted to begin my address by congratulating the people of Canada on the 125th birthday of the Canadian federation. From my heart and on behalf of the entire Russian people, I sincerely congratulate everyone in Canada on this anniversary.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext:
Hear, hear.
June 19, 1992

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext:
Our states are federative in nature. This creates unique opportunities for making the ties between our states better reflect the needs and aspirations of our people. Russia is very interested in studying Canada's experience in managing relations within a federation. We will learn from you how to solve problems in a civilized way through negotiations.
And now a few words about the problems facing the Commonwealth of Independent States of the former union, which are causing many people around the world to worry. This unique intergovernmental organization is currently in the building stage. But it has already proved itself to be a working mechanism for finding the most acceptable form of mutual relations between the republics. At the same time, a process is under way in the Commonwealth whereby republics are both falling apart and coming together. However difficult it may be for us to ensure that this highly complex process remains governable, the seventh and most recent meeting of the heads of government of these countries can be considered the most productive meeting in terms of results.
Respected parliamentarians of Canada, you have considerable opportunities for positively influencing the development of Russian-Canadian co-operation. As I have said before, the advantages to be derived from co-operating with Russia may not all be immediately apparent. They must be explained, but this will not be difficult in the new atmosphere characterizing our relations. I urge you to make active use of your opportunities in Parliament and in the ridings when speaking with the Canadians who elected you to actively promote the dialogue between Russia and Canada, between our peoples.
There is every reason to speak of fundamental national interests shared by Russia and Canada and of human aspirations shared by the ordinary people in our countries. This is what has enabled us, after decades of isolation, to base Russian-Canadian relations on a solid legal foundation: the Treaty on Concord and Co-operation which will be signed today. The community of interests of which I speak cannot be built on thin air. As you know, much is being done in both countries to ensure that it becomes a constant theme of the domestic and foreign policies of our countries.
Speaking from this lofty rostrum, I would especially like to mention Canada's active contribution to the development of the dialogue between us. We are grateful for the solidarity which the people and political leaders of your country showed for a democratic Russia in August. I remember the telephone conversation I had at that time with Prime Minister Mulroney. It had enormous significance, and Russians will never forget it. Russians know about it. Russians remember it, and will continue to remember it for the rest of their history.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: Hear, hear.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext:
Your solidarity has continued in the form of Canadian economic and humanitarian assistance to Russia. We value highly the heroism of individual citizens and organizations, including the Salvation Army's renewed activity in our country.
Today it is no less important or urgent that we learn the language of mutually advantageous co-operation and partnership in business.
We have a clear vision of what we are striving toward in our country, in the world and in our relations with Canada. And many would do well to study the development of our relations.
Our intentions are not secret. We are prepared for hard work, which is the very essence of any partnership. We have a long and difficult road ahead of us. I am convinced that our peoples must travel together if they are to attain the best results.
I want to wish Russians and Canadians a happy journey and success in developing peaceful areas of mutual co-operation. Thank you.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: Hear, hear.

speakeroldname: Hon. Guy Charbonneau (Speaker of the Senate):
subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext:
Mr. President, Mrs. Yeltsin, Mr. Speaker, Mr. Prime Minister, honorables collegues du Senat et de la Chambre des communes, distinguished guests:
[Editor's Note: Mr. Charbonneau spoke in Russian.]
We are honoured by your visit and very grateful that you have shared with us as parliamentary colleagues your international preoccupations and your determination to carry through the program of reform and restructuring upon which your country has launched itself.

June 19, 1992
Your presence in these precincts testifies to your faith in the solid basis of the friendly relations between our two countries and to our confidence in your courageous leadership.
We are all the more touched by your presence here today in that we know very well that you are required to be ubiquitous in order to respond to the exigencies of your post on the national and international levels.
As president of the young Russian federation, your leadership has been and remains preponderant to your people, as it does for the collectivity of nations.
Your remarks to us today confirm your indefatigable will to succeed in attaining your goals.

Mr. President, we are all aware of the balancing act you have to perform, caught as you are between attraction for the West and respect for the Russian soul.
Your great writers of the last century made us keenly aware of these differences between the two societies, both so rich in virtues and so laden with an uncounted heritage.
We remember Dostoyevsky, in particular, who in search of a fair balance between the pro-Western and pro-Slavic forces agreed to modernization for Russia if it respected the nation's traditions.
Like you, he worked for understanding of different cultures. In his tribute to Pushkin, he wrote, "Our vocation is European and universal. Is not being Russian, perfectly Russian, the same perhaps as being a brother to all men?"

In a historical continuity, Tolstoy and Chekov both called for the rejection of a completed past but on the condition that the characteristics of their ancestral customs be preserved. Then, as in our own century, it was the political system in place that was seen as bearing the blame for stagnation and frustrated hopes.
You, Mr. President, have had the courage to confront and repudiate the doctrinaires who were so mistaken about the nature of man.
Without renouncing for the people of your federation their rooted national traditions, you are bringing them into a universal current of liberty.
All the world remembers how you stood up (in every sense of the word) in front of the White House in Moscow, not quite a year ago, to defend liberty and democracy when they were threatened. We are convinced that the same democratic and courageous spirit will carry you forward in the future.
To borrow the language of a sport at which you excel, tennis, we want to wish you, in all your battles with adversity, a final score of game, set, and match.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: Hear, hear.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: Once more, Mr. President, we congratulate you on the eminent and challenging role to which you dedicate yourself in these critical years and we are grateful to you for sharing with us your main concerns and your intention to continue your work in space and time. We thank you and wish you good luck.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: Hear, hear.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext:
Mr. President, Madam Yeltsina, Mr. Prime Minister, Mr. Speaker of the Senate, members of the Senate and the House of Commons, honoured and distinguished guests:
On behalf of all members of the House of Commons I take great pleasure in welcoming you today to this august Chamber.

The momentous changes which have reshaped the global political landscape over the last several years have left us facing new and daunting challenges. Perhaps no country is more acutely aware of this than the Russian Federation.

We are seeing today in Russia and the other new republics of the former Soviet Union one of the most remarkable transformations in history.
Communism is now a fading memory, and in its place have been planted the seeds of democracy. Among the new republics, Russia is taking the lead in sowing these seeds.
You have shown tremendous courage, Mr. President, in introducing bold economic reforms.
June 19, 1992

Russia possesses enormous economic potential, blessed as it is with immense natural and human resources; however, only a continued commitment to economic reform will ensure that these resources are effectively tapped.
We are a sensitive people, Mr. President, and we are aware that the transition to a market economy brings with it unavoidable hardship; the Russian people have displayed patience and courage in the face of economic adversity, and in so doing they have earned the respect and admiration of all Canadians.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: Hear, hear.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext:
We feel certain that, despite the many obstacles that remain, the historic spirit of the Russian people will ultimately prevail.
Canada will do all it can to help. As one of the G-7 countries we helped assemble the recent $24 billion assistance package to Russia which will be tied to an economic reform program devised by the International Monetary Fund.
On a bilateral level, Canada has pledged considerable assistance, and, as you mentioned during your last trip to Ottawa, Mr. President, we have fulfilled all our promises.
We have provided your country with substantial grain and other credits, as well as a wide variety of technical and humanitarian assistance.
We hope that trade and investment ties are also growing.
Clearly, we are in a special position with relation to Russia, a position which we understand, a position that brings a responsibility to us which we want to accept.
Both countries now have an unprecedented opportunity to build on what should be a natural friendship. The last 50 years have perhaps blinded people to the striking similarities and unique ties that exist between our countries.
You mentioned that being here from your country you could feel at home. Canada's vast expanse of land, our northern geography, our climate, our abundant natural
resources, our multicultural tradition, even our hockey tradition-all these we share in common with Russia.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: Hear, hear.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext:
We have taken steps to strengthen these ties.
Part of our technical assistance is aimed at upgrading Russian resource industries such as oil and gas.
As northern neighbours, both countries support the creation of an International Arctic Council which would deal with environmental and security concerns in the region.
Also on the environmental front, which you mentioned, sir, Canada recently pledged to help Russia ensure the safety of its nuclear reactors.
We need to cultivate these bilateral ties.
Perhaps the best way to do it is to encourage people-to-people contact.

In May, the House of Commons held a week-long seminar on the theme of "Canada's Federal System of Government", which attracted delegations from the newly emerging democracies of central and eastern Europe, including one from Russia.
We look forward to more such parliamentary co-operation in the future.

Finally, our countries share a common concern over security. The Cold War is over, and a new era in international politics has emerged.
Canada supports and encourages you, Mr. President, in your continued efforts to preserve regional and international security.
Your recent agreement with President Bush to slash strategic nuclear weapons represents an historic breakthrough, and we trust that relations with your neighbours in the Commonwealth of Independent States will show similar goodwill and co-operation.
Your leadership on this matter, Mr. President, is well known in this country.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext:
Hear, hear.

June 19, 1992

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext:
In closing, Mr. President, let me say on behalf of all who are here today what enormous respect we have for your achievements as President of the Russian Federation during a difficult period. Your courage has been mentioned.
Perhaps it is appropriate to remind ourselves of what Mr. Churchill said once when asked: "What is the greatest quality a person may have?" He said: "Courage, because it secures all others".
Sir, you are an example of that and we are very proud of you.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext: Hear, hear.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext:
We value our growing friendship with your country, and look forward with great eagerness to increasing our ties in the future and helping you in whatever way we can.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, for being with us. You will be welcome again. To you and madam, we wish you good luck and Godspeed.

subsubtopic: PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERATION OF RUSSIA
speechtext:
Hear, hear.

Monday, June 22, 1992
